Resolved Question Show me another » Can your employer deduct Credit Card processing fees from your pay? I suppose a little more information is in order here. To begin with I am asking on behalf of my girlfriend and not myself. She is a server at a local fast food/restaurant place. This company is shady. Constant wage fluctuations and deductions for random things with almost no prior notification etc.
At any rate. She went into work this morning and was informed that the Processing fees for customers paying by credit card will be taken out of the Servers credit card tip if one was left. If none were left it would come automatically out of her pay check. It is only a 2% charge, but I am certain that will eventually add up.
I am curious if this is legal or not, and if it is legal where could I find the appropriate information that touches specifically on this issue. 1 year ago Report Abuse
Additional Details Making a note for possible trolls. She has been looking for another job, but the unemployment rate where we live is 18.9% right now. You're considered lucky if you work for McDonalds cleaning toilets. 1 year ago by Chas Member since: October 30, 2010 Total points: 56,997 (Level 7) Badge Image: Add Contact Block
Best Answer - Chosen by Voters Look under chapter 30 in the handbook for DOL examiners. It has to be only the portion of credit card processing that pertains to the tip. It also explains the fluctuation in wages due to tip income. They can't charge 2% if no tip was left. Source(s): http://www.dol.gov/whd/FOH/index.htm 1 year ago Report Abuse 100% 3 Votes 2 people rated this as good

Other Answers (3) Show: All Answers Oldest to Newest Newest to Oldest Rated Highest to Lowest by Fred Member since: November 12, 2009 Total points: 3,796 (Level 4) Add Contact Block "Processing fees for customers paying by credit card will be taken out of the Servers credit card tip if one was left."
This is legal for the TIP ONLY. The restaurant cannot pass the processing fee for the cost of the meal, taxes etc on to the server.
As for wge fluctuations, the laws regarding wages for tip employees are somewhat different than"normal"employees. Some states require the restaurant to adjust the wages so the combined wages and reported tips at least equal"normal"minimum wge.
